nodes.name: Left anterior insula
nodes.description: For patients with schizophrenia who do not suffer from symptoms of paranoia, there is a decreased sensitivity to facial expressions demonstrating disgust, and an increased sensitivity to sad facial expressions. This is mediated by reduced activity in the left anterior insula. This area also appears to be responsible for auditory hallucinations.

nodes.name: Right anterior insula
nodes.description: There is a decreased sensitivity to fearful faces in patients with schizophrenia. This is mediated by reduced activity in the right anterior insula. Interestingly enough, it appears that smoking nicotine helps improve right insular response in patients with schizophrenia, though this healing effect does not occur in patients without schizophrenia.

nodes.name: Anterior cingulate cortex
nodes.description: The anterior cingulate cortex shows reduced levels of grey matter in patients with schizophrenia, even before the patient is diagnosed. For this reason, the ACC is a particularly important area for predicting schizophrenia onset in children.

nodes.name: Thalamus
nodes.description: The thalamus plays a key role in information processing. Recently it has been hypothesized that there is a disruption in connectivity between the thalamus, the cerebellum, and the prefrontal cortex. A disruption in this circuitry produces something called 'cognitive dysmetria,' which leads to difficulty in prioritizing, processing, coordinating, and responding to information. This 'poor mental coordination' is a large problem for those who suffer from schizophrenia, and can account for a broad diversity of schizophrenia symptoms.

nodes.name: Midbrain
nodes.description: Midbrain activity is correlated with severity of delusions in those with schizophrenia. This appears to stem from assigning inappropriate significance to non-significant events. The midbrain is useful for determining what sort of stimuli is worth paying attention to, and an inappropriate direction of attention appears to be linked to delusional thinking.

nodes.name: Left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
nodes.description: Deficits in working memory in schizophrenia patients are attributable (at least in part) to specific alterations in the neuronal circuitry of the dorsolateral PFC. This is often accompanied by disturbances in how certain neurotransmitters, such as glutamate and dopamine, are regulated in this area. Glutamate and dopamine are the two neurotransmitters most commonly associated with schizophrenia, and patients often show an increased sensitivity to these neurotransmitters.

nodes.name: Dorsomedial prefrontal cortex
nodes.description: In men with schizophrenia, there is a reduced volume of grey matter in the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex. This decrease does not appear to affect women.

nodes.name: Posterior cingulate cortex (precuneus)
nodes.description: About 30-50% of patients with schizophrenia are unaware that they have schizophrenia. Those who demonstrate an awareness of their disorder typically have increased blood flow in the precuneus area. In general, this area is associated with self-awareness.

nodes.name: Left orbitofrontal cortex
nodes.description: In women with schizophrenia, there is a reduced volume of grey matter in the orbitofrontal cortex. This decrease does not appear to affect men.

nodes.name: Medial prefrontal cortex
nodes.description: The medial PFC plays a large role in the mediation of symptoms in schizophrenia, particularly those related to dysfunction in internally directed thought, a state of watchfulness, and the maintenance of one's sense of self. In particular, dysregulation in this area appears to play a central role in paranoia, or unwanted fear and suspicious regarding others’ intentions.

nodes.name: Left temporal cortex
nodes.description: The volume of the temporal cortex tends to decrease over time as psychotic symptoms develop, particularly in the context of stress and drug abuse.

nodes.name: Right temporal cortex

nodes.name: Left middle frontal gyrus
nodes.description: The severity of ‘positive symptoms’ in schizophrenia, such as hallucinations, delusions, and racing thoughts, are correlated with decreased activation in the left middle frontal gyrus.
